Curran,

Thank you! And it only hurts a little.

I bought this tsuba and an=
other from one of the many 'dealers' who 
spout their so-called knowledge o=
f Nihonto but don't know their ass 
from a hole-in-the-ground (and who will=
 remain nameless). I learned 
a very good lesson..........Be very careful a=
bout what you are being 
sold and how much money your spending. Since they =
didn't cost me 
alot, this lesson was worth the money. 

As soon as I take =
some pictures of the other, I will submit them for 
a consult.

The Saotome=
 piece I have in my album is fabulous. I should hope to 
never sell it. 

T=
hanks,

Elliott


--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Curran Campbell

> Elliott,

> The good:
> There are some nice ts=
uba in your in your folder. I
> like the Sukeyoshi and the one labeled Saot=
ome.
> 
> The bad:
> Photos #19 & #20 are of a shiiremono (mass produced)
>=
 tsuba. It might even be one of the better modern
> chinese repros. For stu=
dy's sake, look up Mito
> Shiiremono.
> 
> The ugly:
> There is no sharpnes=
s or crispness to the design. The
> nanako (little beads) are crudely space=
d. The figures
> are poorly cut, and gold washed.
> 
> 
> Curran
